text: David Pascoe Aiers, 12 June 1971 (19 September 1922 – 5 July 1983) was a British diplomat in the Twentieth century.‘AIERS, David Pascoe’, Who Was Who, A & C Black, an imprint of Bloomsbury Publishing plc, 1920–2015; online edn, Oxford University Press, 2014 ; online edn, April 2014 accessed 25 March 2015 ==Education== Aiers was educated at the Stationers' Company's School and Trinity College, Oxford. ==Military Service== Booth was a Captain in the Royal Artillery from 1942 toLondon Gazette 5 February 1943 1946\. ==Career== Aiers joined Her Majesty's Diplomatic Service in 1950. He was Third Secretary in Warsaw from 1946 to 1948 London Gazette 7 December 1948 He was at the Foreign Office from to 1951; Second Secretary at Copenhagen from 1951 to 1953, then Buenos Aires from 1953 to 1955. After another spell at the FO he was First Secretary (Commercial) in Manila from 1958 to 1962; then Head of Chancery in Ankara from 1962London Gazette 8 November 1963 to 1965. He was Counsellor in Singapore from 1965 to 1968; Head of the SW Pacific Department at the FCO from 1968 to 1971; and then Minister at Canberra from 1971 to 1975. He was High Commissioner of the United Kingdom to Sri Lanka (and Ambassador of the United Kingdom to the Maldives from 197615 March 1977 to 1979; and finally, and finally, High Commissioner to Malta from 1979 to 1982. His successor was Charles Leonard Booth.BOOTH, Charles Leonard’, Who Was Who, A & C Black, an imprint of Bloomsbury Publishing plc, 1920–2015; online edn, Oxford University Press, 2014 ; online edn, April 2014 accessed 24 March 2015 ==References== Category:High Commissioners of the United Kingdom to the Maldives Category:High Commissioners of the United Kingdom to Sri Lanka Category:High Commissioners of the United Kingdom to Malta Category:People educated at the Stationers' Company's School Category:Alumni of Trinity College, Oxford Category:Companions of the Order of St Michael and St George Category:1922 births Category:1983 deaths
title: David Aiers
